S4.T1.table:
Domain #Users #Items #Train #Valid #Test Avg.Len
Food 4658 13564 4977 1307 1332 8.79
Kitchen 13382 32918 11100 2172 2254 8.60
Clothing 9240 34909 5720 818 866 9.30
Beauty 5902 17780 4668 836 855 10.29
Movie 34792 44464 57405 10944 11654 7.97
Book 19419 72246 63157 11168 12149 7.20
Game 5588 10336 6631 1374 1444 6.49
Sport 28139 88992 51477 13720 14214 10.65
Garden 6852 21604 10479 3074 3113 9.48
Home 20784 62499 37361 10058 10421 10.41
references: As used in many cross-domain recommendation methods, we utilize the publicly available datasets from Amazon 444https://jmcauley.ucsd.edu/data/amazon/ (an e-commerce platform) to construct the federated CSR scenarios. We select ten domains to generate three cross-domain scenarios: Food-Kitchen-Cloth-Beauty (FKCB), Movie-Book-Game (MBG), and Sports-Garden-Home (SGH). Following the approach of previous studies [3, 2, 1], we remove users and items with fewer than 10 interactions. Additionally, we only preserve sequences that contain a minimum of 4 items, and a maximum of 16 items. For the dataset split, we select the latest 20% of each user’s interactions as the validation/test set, and the remaining 80% interaction sequences as the training set. We summarize the statistics of the federated CSR scenarios in Table 1.

S4.T5.caption: Table 5: Ablation study on FKCB, MBG, and SGH scenarios.
S4.T5.table:
Method FKCB MBG SGH
MRR NDCG MRR NDCG MRR NDCG
@10 @10 @10
LocalVSAN 11.57 13.16 5.63 5.87 2.06 1.96
FedVSAN 10.24 11.37 4.77 5.15 1.21 1.05
LocalContrastVAE 12.11 13.38 8.67 9.24 4.10 4.02
FedContrastVAE 11.84 13.19 8.82 9.75 4.18 4.03
LocalVGSE 13.49 15.30 10.63 11.63 5.24 5.20
FedDCSR - w/o (SRD, CIM) 12.24 14.01 10.31 11.14 5.37 5.32
FedDCSR - w/o CIM 14.17 16.20 10.78 11.67 5.40 5.36
FedDCSR(Ours) 15.24 17.23 11.38 12.49 5.41 5.40
references: We perform an ablation study on FedDCSR by showing how the SRD and CIM affect its performance. Table 5 displays the performance of several model variants in three CSR scenarios. LocalVGSE is the VGSE model without federated aggregation, FedDCSR-w/o (SRD, CIM) is FedDCSR without SRD and CIM, and FedDCSR-w/o CIM is FedDCSR without CIM. We observe that FedDCSR-w/o (SRD, CIM) sometimes performs worse than LocalVGSE, which indicates that the sequence feature heterogeneity is very significant. Additionally, We notice that FedDCSR-w/o CIM performs better than LocalVGSE and FedDCSR-w/o (SRD, CIM), demonstrating the effectiveness of SRD in addressing the feature heterogeneity problem across domains. Finally, CIM allows the model performance to be further improved.
